newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: Seoul body sees foreign debts at over $140 billion.
newsitem.headline: Seoul body sees foreign debts at over $140 billion.

text.p: South Korea's total foreign debts are expected to increase by 30.1 percent this year to $140-150 billion by the end of this year, the private Hyundai Research Institute said on Tuesday.
The amount would represent 27.4 percent of the country's estimated gross domestic product (GDP) at the same time, the institute said in a report.
As of the end of February, the report estimated the nation's total foreign debts at about $111 billion, or 22.9 percent of GDP, it said.
A widening current account deficit, a result of falling prices of the country's major export items and the local currency's depreciation, has been blamed for the rising debts.
The institute forcast this year's current account deficit would narrow to around $20 billion, against the government's projection of a $18 billion shortfall.
Last year, South Korea's current account deficit rose to a record $23.72 billion from a $8.95 billion shortfall in 1995.
The institute said South Korea would have to pay about $13-14 billion in debt servicing. It gave no comparable figures for last year.
